pull.title: Add Stale Bot configuration
pull.body:
It might be a good idea to add the [Stale Bot](https://github.com/marketplace/stale) to close issues and pulls that do not receive any activity for a certain period instead of doing it manually once in a while. The timeout in this PR is configured to be 6 months.

> How it works
> After a period of inactivity, a label will be applied to mark an issue as stale, and optionally post a comment to notify contributors that the Issue or Pull Request will be closed.
> 
> If the Issue or Pull Request is updated, or anyone comments, then the stale label is removed.
> 
> If no more activity occurs, the Issue or Pull Request will be automatically closed with an optional comment.

This could also help revive old pulls/issues that were forgotten by receiving the notification from the bot.

Note: Merging the PR is not sufficient to activate the bot, it needs to be activated by maintainers [here](https://github.com/marketplace/stale). See also https://github.com/probot/stale#usage.

verification.payload:
tree 6a42f6ed8ea4af00f6e5c7ed3575dc5e45222ed8
parent 1d277f42236d6074ea84c407ae0863ae943f27e4
author Aurèle Oulès <aurele@oules.com> 1665599116 +0200
committer Aurèle Oulès <aurele@oules.com> 1665599529 +0200

Add Stale Bot configuration

events.body: Friendly ping as you might be interested @achow101 @glozow considering you're closing stale pulls.
Seems interesting. I believe it is difficult to manage which PRs look "abandoned" and which PRs are lacking reviewing.
We already have a drahtbot that does something very similar.

Drahtbot does do part of this, but not the closing part. The issue with closing of "stale" PRs is the determination of staleness. It is context dependent, for example PRs that are the parents of a project may become "stale" but shouldn't be closed. The author of a PR also has an effect on staleness, e.g. a frequent contributor having a "stale" PR is probably more likely to come back and update the PR when prompted vs. a one time drive-by contribution may not get any follow-up.
Does this also have the issue of contributors not being able to reopen their own PRs that have been closed by this bot?

> for example PRs that are the parents of a project may become "stale" but shouldn't be closed

I believe these are edge-cases. Since there is a delay before the PR/issue is closed (7 days here), a maintainer could remove the `Stale` tag every 6 months or anyone could write a comment. Also, I believe that usually these parent PRs get activity by being referenced in sub-PRs so the delay before being stale is usually extended.

This may be preferable to having to manually check the activity of all PRs every once in a while?

> Does this also have the issue of contributors not being able to reopen their own PRs that have been closed by this bot?

I'm not familiar with GitHub permissions sorry.

Personally I don't see the problem of open pull requests that are uncontroversial and maintained by their author. Surely if someone walks away or if something is controversial, it may be better to close. Also, I prefer if people raised their concern instead of silently hoping that a pull they don't like goes stale.

So if the goal is for the bot to achieve that, it might be better for it to provide actionable instructions. Similar to https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/19876#issuecomment-1073871847

Some ideas:

* If there is outstanding feedback, it should be replied to or otherwise addressed
* If the CI fails or the last run is older than 6 months, it might be good to rebase to get a fresh CI run and also update the code context to the latest state to simplify review (obviously only if there hasn't been any ACKs to avoid invalidating them)

issue.title: Webhook server and framework for bot features with ACK tracker
issue.body:
This PR adds a new summary comment that appears at the top of every (new) pull request.
It contains an ACK tracker that works as follows:

When a user comments or adds a review (edits and deletions are detected) or the PR author pushes to the PR, the bot will rescan every comment and review for ACKs.
An `ACK` can be a `(N)ACK`, `Concept (N)ACK`, `Approach (N)ACK`, `Code Review (N)ACK`, and `Stale ACK`.

For a raw `ACK` to be valid, a commit hash that matches the PR's head is expected (`ACK <commit sha>`).
If the commit hash no longer matches the PR's head, it goes stale. 
Concept ACKs, Code Review ACKs, Approach ACKs, and NACKs don't require a commit hash but one can be specified so that if the commit referenced no longer matches the head, the 'ACK' will be removed from the tracker automatically.
The case of the comment does not matter and takes into account ACK aliases such as re-ACK, reACK, utACK, crACK, etc.

Specifically, this PR:
- Adds a webhook server for receiving GitHub events of a repository
- Adds a framework for adding features to the Bot, with different event types
- Adds the summary comment feature

There is currently no secret-based webhook authentication but it can be done if this PR is Concept ACKed.

<details>
<summary>Summary comment</summary>

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22493292/199021732-8b5c1c6e-6636-4d3a-9659-00b6ba3ea8cc.png)

</details>

<details>
<summary>ACK example</summary>

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22493292/199023038-bc4c58ee-9f82-4e1c-b858-289f6def4791.png)

</details>

<details>
<summary>Stale ACK</summary>

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22493292/199024155-a54de3ac-94df-4c64-a75f-96afd1364954.png)


</details>

Links in the `Reviewers` cell will automatically scroll down to the specific review.

events.body: Concept NACK - I don't see how this (contextless) bot is going to be beneficial, or better than drahtbot + maintainers. Now that drahtbot is open for contrbutions, I'd rather see any enhancements made there.
Yes, I am currently working on DrahtBot. Closing.

This is now live.

Code: https://github.com/MarcoFalke/DrahtBot/commit/e5f9ff1cbeda1ba603afc0d042dba79610836e8c
Example: https://github.com/bitcoin-core/gui/pull/37#issuecomment-1308567630

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,57 @@
+# Configuration for probot-stale - https://github.com/probot/stale
+
+# Number of days of inactivity before an Issue or Pull Request becomes stale
+daysUntilStale: 180 # 6 months
+
+# Number of days of inactivity before an Issue or Pull Request with the stale label is closed.
+# Set to false to disable. If disabled, issues still need to be closed manually, but will remain marked as stale.
+daysUntilClose: 7
comments.body: Not sure if this can be done by the bot. Sometimes additional stuff needs to be done, like marking "up for grabs" or closing a related issue as well, etc ...

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,57 @@

+

comments.body: It might be easier to implement these features in Drahtbot, do you plan to open-source it?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,57 @@
+# Configuration for probot-stale - https://github.com/probot/stale

comments.body: It would also be nice if Drahtbot could automatically add to a PR the labels "Concept ACK", "Approach ACK" and even count current ACKs, that way it's easy to quickly glance at the state of a PR, or even filter PRs for reviewers. I believe @JeremyRubin had a similar idea.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,57 @@
+# Configuration for probot-stale - https://github.com/probot/stale
+
+# Number of days of inactivity before an Issue or Pull Request becomes stale
+daysUntilStale: 180 # 6 months
+
+# Number of days of inactivity before an Issue or Pull Request with the stale label is closed.
+# Set to false to disable. If disabled, issues still need to be closed manually, but will remain marked as stale.
+daysUntilClose: 7
comments.body: Yeah, I wanted to do that for a long time as well. Though, @DrahtBot is currently written such that it needs to scan every comment, so it will run into the rate limit quite fast.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,57 @@
+# Configuration for probot-stale - https://github.com/probot/stale
+
+# Number of days of inactivity before an Issue or Pull Request becomes stale
+daysUntilStale: 180 # 6 months
+
+# Number of days of inactivity before an Issue or Pull Request with the stale label is closed.
+# Set to false to disable. If disabled, issues still need to be closed manually, but will remain marked as stale.
+daysUntilClose: 7
comments.body:
> it will run into the rate limit quite fast

This could be fixed by using webhooks no? When a comment/review is added to a PR Drahbot could fetch the PR's comments and apply labels. Fetching comments is limited to 100 per req, which is probably fine for most PRs and could also be cached.
And another webhook for when a user pushes to a PR, Drahbot would invalidate ACKs by removing the label.

The rate-limit doesn't seem too restrictive either? Unless I'm missing something
> User-to-server requests are limited to 5,000 requests per hour and per authenticated user

I'd love to work on this but the code is nowhere to be found :frog:.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,57 @@
+# Configuration for probot-stale - https://github.com/probot/stale
+
+# Number of days of inactivity before an Issue or Pull Request becomes stale
+daysUntilStale: 180 # 6 months
+
+# Number of days of inactivity before an Issue or Pull Request with the stale label is closed.
+# Set to false to disable. If disabled, issues still need to be closed manually, but will remain marked as stale.
+daysUntilClose: 7
comments.body: I am not sure how reliably webhooks are. If they are down or otherwise missed, it wouldn't be possible to catch up, unless you have  script to catch up, in which case you can just use that script all the time.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,57 @@
+# Configuration for probot-stale - https://github.com/probot/stale
+
+# Number of days of inactivity before an Issue or Pull Request becomes stale
+daysUntilStale: 180 # 6 months
+
+# Number of days of inactivity before an Issue or Pull Request with the stale label is closed.
+# Set to false to disable. If disabled, issues still need to be closed manually, but will remain marked as stale.
+daysUntilClose: 7
comments.body: If a webhook is missed, which I believe is relatively rare, the bot will catch up on the next webhook received (the next comment/review/push), because it will rescan the PR comments. I don't think it's that big of a deal to miss an event, this feature is to provide heuristics anyway.

comments.body: The source code is of low quality, but I just made it public. See for example https://github.com/MarcoFalke/DrahtBot/blob/main/scripts/stale.py
